resources.string: A circuitboard which you plug other components in to.
Geared towards individuals, these less powerful computeres are easier to make; but consumers replace them fairly often.
Geared towards businesses, these more powerful computers are harder to make and must be stable; but businesses don't upgrade often.
A serial port or ethernet port (when internet comes around) to work with the server, when you can't just be local to it.
Allows you to remotely turn the server on/off.
Allows you to remotely press certain keys, often useful to stop a server from rebooting.
Allows you to actually see what's on the screen, and interact with the server remotely.
Allows you hear what's going on the server, such as music or local input devices.
Exists to keep the system time, configuration, and allow for logging systems to flush when the system loses power.
Allows for configuration management, log viewing, and tweaking of the computer system.
he BIOS just wasn't good enough ...
Somewhere to shove that fine thinkin' brain of yours.
Adds support for Daughter Boards, which can be added to the Computer to increase processing power.
Adding features to the BIOS/UEFI that let the user control the speed of their Processor, which also creates more heat and is unstable.
THIS MAKES YOU THEIR ISP, WATCH YOUR BANDWIDTH
Two network interfaces configured in a mode called 'bonding' which allows them to handle packets for each other. Considered to be more stable than having only one.
Slots that let users install additional hardware, currently only Graphics Cards require PCI.
A bus dedicated to graphics adapters.
A bus dedicated to graphics adapters x8.
A much faster version of PCI, must match the Graphics Cards being used.
Allows for the use of two graphics cards.
Now you can fit three graphics cards.
Allows you to plug in peripherals such as a Keyboard or Mouse.
The system can use fans to cool down.
Wow! Plug all your stuffs in!
Plug in those fancy ear muff things that make noise!
It's almost as if you were there
That thing you always plug into your PC the wrong side... USB
Now with faster data transfer, figuring out which side are you going to plug it in in the dark is still terrible
Woooo, a rapid fast USB colored in blue!
